Title.evidence: Virtual Reality for Postoperative Pain Management: A Randomised Controlled Trial

Trial_Design.evidence: Participants were randomised to receive either 2–8-minute-long three-dimensional immersive VR presentations or two-dimensional nature films with neutral music.

Participants.evidence: 106 adults undergoing elective primary total hip arthroplasty at a single hospital.

Intervention.evidence: Participants were randomised to receive either 2–8-minute-long three-dimensional immersive VR presentations or two-dimensional nature films with neutral music.

Objective.evidence: This randomised controlled trial evaluated whether a virtual reality (VR) program reduces acute postoperative pain and opioid requirements in patients recovering from hip arthroplasty.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was pain after VR or sham video presentations, adjusted for pre-treatment scores, measured on a 0–10 scale.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was computer-generated, and allocation was concealed.

Blinding.evidence: Patients and outcome assessors were blinded to group assignments.

Number_Randomised.evidence: 52 patients were randomised to VR and 54 to sham presentations.

Result_Outcome.evidence: The mean difference in pain scores was −0.1 points [95% CI: −0.5, 0.2, P=0.391].
